solution_line_template: First, we need to determine how many slices the pizza was cut into. To do this, we start by performing {initial_slices}*{first_cut_multiplier}= <<{initial_slices}*{first_cut_multiplier}={slices_after_first_cut}>>{slices_after_first_cut} slices after the pizza was cut in half once.

Each of these slices was cut in half again, yielding {slices_after_first_cut}*{second_cut_multiplier}= <<{slices_after_first_cut}*{second_cut_multiplier}={total_pizza_slices}>>{total_pizza_slices} slices in total.

Next, we divide the total amount of pepperoni slices by the number of pizza slices, as the pepperoni was spread evenly. We find there are {total_pepperoni}/{total_pizza_slices}= <<{total_pepperoni}/{total_pizza_slices}={pepperoni_per_slice}>>{pepperoni_per_slice} slices of pepperoni per pizza slice.

Since {fallen_pepperoni} slice of pepperoni fell off Jelly's slice, this means there are {pepperoni_per_slice}-{fallen_pepperoni}=<<{pepperoni_per_slice}-{fallen_pepperoni}={pepperoni_on_jelly_slice}>>{pepperoni_on_jelly_slice} slices left on her slice.
